awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of an Automated Collection and Extraction System (ACES) for Off- or On-line Chemical Analysis of Organic Aerosol Species
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation project will focus on the development of a device to automatically collect and extract organic aerosols from the ambient atmosphere.  The system will be compared with conventional samplers in the laboratory and during field sampling campaigns.  Automated low-cost aerosol sampling devices are needed for chemical characterization of ambient air pollution.

The key features of the instrument will be: (1) reduction of sampling and decomposition artifacts characteristic of filter-based and thermal desorption instruments; (2) a combination of a small particle deposit area with ultra-low solvent volumes, of the order of a microliter, that allows the device to achieve high time resolution and sensitivity; (3) solvent extraction that preserves the chemical composition of the sample; (4) the extraction efficiency is enhanced by using elevated solvent temperature and pressure; and (5) the flexibility of use, as it can be used for off-line collection or coupled to an online instrument.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric aerosols, minuscule particles suspended in the air, play a significant role in various natural phenomena, including the formation of fogs and clouds. They are accountable for reduced visibility, often referred to as haze, and can adversely impact human health. These aerosols are composed of a diverse array of chemicals, which dictate their properties and subsequent effects on the environment and health. Understanding the chemical composition of atmospheric aerosols is crucial in determining their origin and fate in the atmosphere, underscoring the importance of accurate aerosol chemical composition measurements.

Ambient aerosol concentration and composition can undergo significant alterations within a single day due to fluctuating aerosol sources. For instance, in urban areas, morning rush hour sees aerosols dominated by traffic emissions, while noon and early afternoon hours witness aerosols primarily from other sources, such as cooking and atmospheric chemical reactions. Consequently, aerosol composition measurements are required on an hourly scale.

Regrettably, current sampling methods depend on filter measurements that necessitate extended sampling times, typically at least 8 hours or longer. These filter measurements also demand considerable effort, as all procedures, including filter handling and extraction for chemical analysis, are manual. In recent years, several automated instruments have been developed for measuring aerosol chemical composition with an hourly time resolution. However, these instruments rely on heating the collected aerosol material to analyze its composition, a process known to cause decomposition of some aerosol constituents, thereby skewing the measurements.

In this project, we have developed a prototype of an Automated Collection and Extraction System (ACES) that automatically collects and extracts ambient aerosols using various solvents. As no heating is required, decomposition of the collected material is effectively avoided. The ACES was subjected to laboratory experiments to assess its efficiency in collecting particles of diverse sizes and its capability to dissolve and recover aerosol constituents.

The ACES can collect particles as small as 85 nanometers and can efficiently extract the collected material. Given the small volume of solvent used for extraction, the ACES can collect sufficient material within an hour to detect 1 nanogram of a substance in a cubic meter of air. This level of sensitivity and time resolution is adequate for measurements in most locations.
